questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Coxsackievirus: 

Feature

Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative Agent

Coxsackieviruses, particularly Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71

Clinical Presentation
  • Painful sores/ulcers in the mouth
  • Rash/blisters on hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks
  • Mild to high fever

Transmission

Close personal contact, respiratory droplets, contaminated surfaces

Incubation Period

3-6 days (range: 2-10 days)

Course and Prognosis

Self-limiting, resolves within 7-10 days

Treatment and Management

Supportive care, pain relief for mouth sores, hydration

Complications

Dehydration, viral meningitis, encephalitis (rare)

questions.text: Which among the following drug is not used in the treatment of acne vulgaris?
questions.explanation:
Grades

Lesions

Treatment

Grade I

Non-inflammatory lesions such as open (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads)

Topical retinoids

(Tretinoin, Adapalene)

Grade II

Non-inflammatory lesions (comedones) + inflammatory lesions such as papules and few pustules.

Topical retinoids + Topical antibiotics

Grade III

Multiple inflammatory papules and pustules ± nodules (moderate)

Topical retinoids + Oral antibiotics ± Benzoyl peroxide

Grade IV

Nodules + Cysts

(Most severe form)

Oral retinoids

(Isotretinoin)

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 40-year-old woman who experienced fever and joint pain, and subsequently developed a lesion on her nose a few days after taking NSAIDs?
What could be the potential cause of the following lesions in a gardener who has a history of thorn pricks?
Identify the type of skin lesion:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Annular

Skin Lesion

Description

Examples

Macule

Flat, discolored spot on the skin with no palpable elevation or depression.

Freckles, flat moles

Patch

Large, flat, maculopapular area of skin discoloration.

Vitiligo, café-au-lait spots

Papule

Small, solid, elevated lesion with a palpable surface.

Acne, warts

Plaque

Elevated, flat-topped lesion with a broad, flat surface.

Psoriasis plaques, seborrheic keratosis

Vesicle

Small, fluid-filled blister, usually less than 5mm in diameter.

Chickenpox blisters, herpes simplex

Bulla

Large, fluid-filled blister, typically more than 5mm in diameter.

Bullous pemphigoid, second-degree burns

Pustule

Small, elevated lesion filled with pus.

Acne pustules, impetigo

Wheal

Transient, raised, and edematous lesion with irregular borders, often associated with itching or allergic reactions.

Insect bite reactions, hives (urticaria)

Nodule

Solid, palpable lesion, often deeper in the skin layers.

Dermatofibroma, lipoma

Tumor

Solid, elevated lesion larger than a few centimeters in diameter.

Basal cell carcinoma, melanoma

Plaque

Large, flat, elevated lesion with a flat surface and a diameter greater than its height.

Psoriasis plaques, lichen planus

Burrow

Linear or serpignious tunnel in the skin caused by infestation or burrowing of parasites.

Scabies burrows

Scale

Dry, flaky, or thickened skin with shedding of dead skin cells.

Psoriasis scales, seborrheic dermatitis

Crust

Dried exudate or secretion on the skin surface.

Impetigo crusts, dried blood crusts

Erosion

Loss of the superficial epidermis, resulting in a moist, shallow depression.

Aphthous ulcers, erosion due to scratching

Ulcer

Loss of the entire epidermis and at least part of the dermis, resulting in a deep, open lesion.

Pressure ulcers, venous ulcers

Fissure

Linear crack or slit-like split in the skin.

Athlete's foot fissures, anal fissures

Scar

Fibrous tissue that replaces normal skin after injury or surgery.

Surgical scars, keloids

Atrophy

Thinning or depression of the skin with loss of normal skin markings.

Striae (stretch marks), aged skin

questions.text: What is the appropriate next course of action for a child who exhibits itchy scalp lesions and hair loss, as depicted in the image provided?
A female patient presented with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best investigation?

A 60-year-old male patient presents with the lesion given in the image below. He also mentions experiencing sensations like a spider crawling in the area of the lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Etiology

Reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) from latency in sensory ganglia.

Risk Factors

Immunosuppression, aging (>50 years), stress, malignancy, chronic diseases (diabetes).

Clinical Features

Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base along a single dermatome (usually thoracic, lumbar, or trigeminal).

Prodromal Symptoms

Burning, tingling, paresthesia ("spider crawling sensation"), fever, malaise before rash appears.

Complications

Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN), bacterial superinfection, ophthalmic zoster (if V1 of trigeminal nerve is involved).

Diagnosis

Clinical; Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells), PCR for VZV in doubtful cases.

Treatment

Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) within 72 hours, analgesics, corticosteroids (if severe pain).

Prevention

Zoster vaccine for elderly and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 7-year-old boy with intellectual disability who has developed extensive warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet, along with severe fissuring and scaling on the soles of his feet?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Classic Scabies

Crusted (Norwegian) Scabies

Prevalence

More common

Less common

Skin Lesions

Small erythematous papules, "knots on a rope"

Erythematous, scaling, crusting, and fissuring

Pruritus

Severe, worse at night

Usually mild or absent due to nerve damage

Onset

3-6 weeks after initial colonization, 1-3 days after reinfestation

Gradual but progressive

Risk Factors

No specific immunosuppression required

Occurs in immunosuppressed patients (HIV, elderly, cancer, etc.)

Mite Burden

Low mite burden

High mite burden

Transmission

Direct skin-to-skin contact

More commonly transmitted via fomites (objects)

Common Sites

Webs of fingers, axillae, areola, genitalia

Hands, feet, and scalp

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:

Feature

Details

Etiology

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes

Types

Non-bullous (crusted), Bullous

Lesion

Common Sites

Face (perioral, perinasal), extremities

Treatment

Topical mupirocin, oral antibiotics if extensive

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a farmer who has a swollen foot and multiple discharging sinuses, as depicted in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.
  • Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).
  • Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp.

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.
